author: By Ali Watkins
title: Over $150,000 in Fines Issued on First Weekend of New N.Y.C. Lockdown
description: At least five houses of worship were given a summons in the neighborhoods where the coronavirus infection rates are the highest.
content: Authorities cracked down this weekend on some of the city’s coronavirus hot spots, issuing more than 60 summonses and tens of thousands of dollars in fines to people, businesses and houses of worship that did not follow newly imposed restrictions on gatherings or mask-wearing and social-distancing requirements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: QAnon Is Thriving in Germany. The Extreme Right Is Delighted.
description: As the U.S. conspiracy theory goes global, it has found fertile ground in the putsch fantasies and anti-Semitic tropes long popular on Germany’s far-right fringe. Counterterrorism officials worry.
content: BERLIN — Early in the pandemic, as thousands of American troops began NATO maneuvers in Germany, Attila Hildmann did a quick YouTube search to see what it was all about. He quickly came across videos posted by German followers of QAnon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Coronavirus surge, North Korea, Rafael Nadal: Here’s what you need to know.
content: More than one million new cases were reported around the world in the past three days, as France, Russia, Nepal and several American states set records for the highest daily number of new infections. India surpassed seven million total cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Gray and Lucy Tompkins
title: Kidnapping Plot Against Whitmer Becomes Part of Michigan Politics
description: The F.B.I. and state authorities last week arrested 13 men in connection with a domestic terrorism plot directed against the first-term governor.
content: BAY CITY, Mich. — The fallout from a failed domestic terrorism plot to overthrow Michigan’s state government and kidnap Gov. Gretchen Whitmer has quickly become embedded in state politics and the presidential race in a key swing state during the final weeks of the campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein, Nick Corasaniti and Stephanie Saul
title: Absentee voting in several key states is favoring Democrats.
description: In Madison, Wis., thousands of people have gone to parks to deliver their ballots during Saturday voting festivals. In Milwaukee, Facebook feeds are inundated with selfies of Democrats inserting ballots into drop boxes. And along the shores of Lake Superior, voters in Wisconsin’s liberal northwest corner still trust the Postal Service to deliver ballots.
content: In Madison, Wis., thousands of people have gone to parks to deliver their ballots during Saturday voting festivals. In Milwaukee, Facebook feeds are inundated with selfies of Democrats inserting ballots into drop boxes. And along the shores of Lake Superior, voters in Wisconsin’s liberal northwest corner still trust the Postal Service to deliver ballots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Rafael Nadal Routs Novak Djokovic at French Open to Catch Roger Federer
description: Rafael Nadal won his 20th Grand Slam men’s singles championship to tie Roger Federer’s record. It was Nadal’s 13th title at the French Open.
content: Neither Novak Djokovic nor Roger Federer could resist Rafael Nadal on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola, Sopan Deb and Marc Stein
title: How the Lakers Won the N.B.A. Title Over the Heat
description: The Miami Heat had forced a sixth game against the Los Angeles Lakers behind a strong performance by Jimmy Butler.
content: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — It was not a season. For the Los Angeles Lakers, it was an obstacle course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Bingaman-Burt
title: Draw Your Life, One Coffee Mug at a Time
description: Taking the time to sketch your belongings can help capture moments and memories.
content: Find an old receipt in your wallet. Feel that thin paper on your fingers, and look at the inky machine type. Why is this telling you to have a nice day? Did you? Instead of throwing the receipt away, draw it. It’s not only a marker of money spent — a replacement for the cash that was once in its place — but of a real moment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘David’s Ankles’
description: A writer’s obsession with the flaws, reproductions and potential collapse of Michelangelo’s masterpiece.
content: There are cracks in the ankles of Michelangelo’s David. The weakness was first discovered in the 19th century, but it wasn’t until a paper by Italian geoscientists was published in 2014 that the extent of the statue’s precariousness was fully understood: If the David were to be tilted 15 degrees, his ankles would fail.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: C.D.C.’s Director Is Challenged to ‘Stand Up to a Bully’
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 11, 2020.
content: “As much as we want to believe we can operate independently of politics and it’s all about science, it took just a few months to hobble our ability to steer the course of this pandemic. So we can pretend that the politics don’t matter, but we have been kneecapped.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: What ‘The Babylon Bee’ Thinks Is So Funny About Liberals
description: The comedy site, a conservative answer to ‘The Onion,’ used to have Trump squarely in its cross hairs. But now it’s less about him and more about the people who can’t stand him.
content: Four years ago, in the heat of the Republican primary, a fledgling satire site jabbed at the party’s leading contender: “Psychopathic Megalomaniac Somehow Garnering Evangelical Vote.” The story proceeded to describe Donald Trump as “a man who would seemingly have no qualms obliterating hundreds of thousands of people for purely egotistical reasons.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 11, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Oct. 11, 2020.
content: A picture caption with an opinion article on Sept. 27 about blackface in film and television misidentified an actor. He is Mark Proksch, not Rainn Wilson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Jets Start 0-5 for Third Time in Franchise History
description: Arizona quarterback Kyler Murray scored two touchdowns as the Cardinals stopped their two-game losing streak and beat the Jets, 30-10, at MetLife Stadium.
content: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. (AP) — The Arizona Cardinals came to MetLife Stadium and, like every other team this season, found a remedy for their woes with a game against a winless team from New York’s rotten football apple.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: N.F.L. Reshuffles Schedule After Rash of Coronavirus Cases
description: The league rescheduled several games in the already crowded calendar as it postponed a Patriots-Broncos matchup.
content: The N.F.L. has rescheduled Monday’s game between the Denver Broncos and the New England Patriots to next week, and reshuffled several other games on the league’s cluttered schedule to accommodate a rash of positive tests for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Could Voting by Mail Affect the Election? Look at Michigan
description: Vote-by-mail has become one of the most contentious issues of the 2020 election. But while battles rage on social media and in the courts, a group of bipartisan Michigan election officials worry they won’t have the time or resources to ensure results on election night.
content: The coronavirus pandemic has made voting by mail one of the election’s most contentious issues. More than 25 states have expanded access to universal mail voting, a move President Trump has repeatedly, and erroneously, equated with a fraudulent election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters and Michael M. Grynbaum
title: After refusing to participate in the second presidential debate, Trump retreats to conservative media safe spaces.
description: When President Trump picked someone to conduct his first on-camera interview since testing positive for the coronavirus, he made the safest of choices: Dr. Marc Siegel, a physician and Fox News personality who has criticized Democratic governors for closing down schools and businesses to fight the pandemic.
content: When President Trump picked someone to conduct his first on-camera interview since testing positive for the coronavirus, he made the safest of choices: Dr. Marc Siegel, a physician and Fox News personality who has criticized Democratic governors for closing down schools and businesses to fight the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Goldfarb
title: How to Connect With the Co-Workers You’re Missing
description: What you gain with remote work — increased flexibility and productivity — comes at the expense of interacting and socializing with colleagues in person. Here are some tips to help deal with that.
content: J’Leen Manning Saeger misses her friends from work. As a Spanish lecturer at Trinity University in San Antonio, Ms. Manning Saegar and other members of her tight-knit department would regularly bounce ideas off one another and discuss their upcoming projects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: C.E.O.s Rediscover the Family Dinner Table
description: Remote work during the coronavirus pandemic has given executives with children a taste of a different way to live.
content: Before the coronavirus pandemic, John Foley, the chief executive and founder of Peloton, and his wife, Jill, a vice president at Peloton, would leave the house each morning by 7:45 a.m. and not come home until 7:30 p.m. By then, their nanny had already fed and gotten their two children ready for bed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: In Belarus, Women Led the Protests and Shattered Stereotypes
description: The women who organized the political campaign and the subsequent protests against President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko may ultimately be defeated. But society may never be the same.
content: MINSK, Belarus — With masked riot police officers massing nearby, threatening to attack protesters like him with batons and fists, Aleksei D. Zulevsky felt safe for the first time in weeks of anti-government unrest in Belarus: He was surrounded by hundreds of women he knew would shield him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger, Ben Hubbard and Farnaz Fassihi
title: For Trump, Defying Mideast Truisms Produced Breakthroughs and Backfires
description: Disregarding norms and accepted wisdom, President Trump went his own way in the Middle East and, in some cases, got what he wanted.
content: JERUSALEM — He moved the American Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem, breaking with those who said it would ignite the Muslim world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: ‘I Feel Like I Have Dementia’: Brain Fog Plagues Covid Survivors
description: The condition is affecting thousands of patients, impeding their ability to work and function in daily life.
content: After contracting the coronavirus in March, Michael Reagan lost all memory of his 12-day vacation in Paris, even though the trip was just a few weeks earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Save the Planet, Win a Prize
description: Rising seas, raging fires, hotter temperatures — and a bit of positivity.
content: At a time when elected officials appear stymied by the challenge of climate change, or even in denial about it, it is heartening to see a royal prince pitch in with a good initiative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: With Elections Ahead, Some African Presidents Try Engineering Results
description: Presidential elections are scheduled soon in at least 10 African countries. Many incumbents are changing constitutions and bending rules to ensure they stay in power.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — The president of the West African nation of Guinea is running for a third term on Oct. 18, even though Guinea requires its presidents to step down after two. But because of a constitutional change he initiated, his first two terms don’t count.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Lewis Hamilton Ties Michael Schumacher’s Wins Record in Germany
description: Hamilton won his 91st Formula 1 race at the Eifel Grand Prix, with Schumacher’s record for titles in sight.
content: NÜRBURG, Germany — Even Lewis Hamilton once saw Michael Schumacher’s record of 91 wins in Formula 1 as unbeatable. Now he’s matched it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Dodgers and Braves Have Won With the Home Run. Can They Win Without It?
description: They were the top two teams in hitting the long ball. But Globe Life Field in Arlington, Texas, which will host the N.L.C.S., has proved to be stingy.
content: The first two rounds of the Major League Baseball playoffs reflected the modern game: lots and lots of home runs. In 11 of the 12 series before Sunday, 54.8 percent of all runs were scored on homers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump surrogates deflected questions about the coronavirus and the debate.
description: As President Trump continued to trail by double digits in polls, several of his surrogates tried on Sunday to shift attention away from the details of his coronavirus infection and his administration’s handling of the pandemic.
content: As President Trump continued to trail by double digits in polls, several of his surrogates tried on Sunday to shift attention away from the details of his coronavirus infection and his administration’s handling of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: For Novak Djokovic, Another Well-Meaning Effort Goes Off the Rails
description: Djokovic, the world No. 1, has tried repeatedly this year to build on his reputation as a leader and a champion. The results have been less than great.
content: Novak Djokovic may look back on these last months as some of the most dreadful in his career, a series of moments that appeared to be filled with opportunity but fizzled in spectacular fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby McGanney Nolan
title: Black and White and Living Color
description: “The Talk” and “This Is Your Brain on Stereotypes” offer two very different approaches to helping children understand and confront bias.
content: THE TALKConversations About Race, Love & TruthEdited by Wade Hudson and Cheryl Willis Hudson
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Can Trump Squeeze More From His White Base in Pennsylvania and Beyond?
description: With President Trump trailing Joseph R. Biden Jr. in Pennsylvania in nearly every poll, his last refuge and perhaps best hope is to maximize the turnout of working-class white voters.
content: OLYPHANT, Pa. — President Trump’s narrowing path to victory in Pennsylvania, and the country, runs through small towns like Olyphant, where Dave Mitchko’s street might be quieter if not for the large sign he put on his front lawn urging supporters of the president to honk when they pass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Why Are N.F.L. Scores So High This Season?
description: Some look to the effects of the disruptions caused by the pandemic, while others find other explanations. But it’s irrefutable teams are scoring more points than in last season.
content: Taking place during a global pandemic, the 2020 N.F.L. season always figured to be an outlier, and predictably there have been persistent coronavirus outbreaks, a hastily restructured playing schedule and games contested in stark, empty stadiums.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathaniel Popper
title: When Your Last $166 Vanishes: ‘Fast Fraud’ Surges on Payment Apps
description: People are getting defrauded as they turn to Square’s Cash App and PayPal’s Venmo to do more online banking in the pandemic.
content: Charee Mobley, who teaches middle school in Fort Worth, Texas, had just $166 to get herself and her 17-year-old daughter through the last two weeks of August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cristian Farias
title: Kamala Harris Should Grill Amy Coney Barrett
description: Senate Democrats would be wise to let Joe Biden’s running mate lead their questioning at the nominee’s confirmation hearing.
content: Millions of Americans have already cast votes ahead of the election, and democracy demands that one of the candidates on the ballot be the Democrats’ lead questioner at the confirmation hearing for Amy Coney Barrett that begins Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry and Judith Levitt
title: Campaign rallies, Trump properties, Hurricane Delta: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Katherine J. Wu and Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Offering few details, the White House doctor says Trump is no longer contagious.
description: President Trump’s doctor said in a memo released Saturday night that he was “no longer considered a transmission risk to others,” as the president prepared to resume campaign activities this week.
content: President Trump’s doctor said in a memo released Saturday night that he was “no longer considered a transmission risk to others,” as the president prepared to resume campaign activities this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Has a Theory About the Fly That Landed on Mike Pence’s Head
description: “Saturday Night Live” satirized Wednesday’s vice-presidential debate in an episode of comedy monologues guaranteed to press everyone’s buttons.
content: From the moment that an errant fly touched down on Vice President Mike Pence during Wednesday’s vice-presidential debate, “Saturday Night Live” viewers started imploring the show to recreate the awkward moment. And “S.N.L.” did just that — at some extravagant length — in this weekend’s opening sketch, leading off an episode full of comedy monologues that were certain to offend almost every sensibility and political viewpoint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano and Hilary Moss
title: Discover the Culinary History of Witchcraft and Join a Digital Self-Care ‘Crawl’
description: Enjoy a reading from Marilynne Robinson’s new book, attend the opening night of a film fest and take the kids on a virtual tour of a museum for musical instruments.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly DiNardo
title: Rest Better With Light Exercises
description: Stretching and meditative movement like yoga before bed can improve the quality of your sleep and the amount you sleep. Here is a short and calming routine of 11 stretches and exercises.
content: Sleep should be a welcome respite, but with our regular routines upended and an almost daily onslaught of anxiety-inducing news, many people are tossing and turning. A study published in June by the journal Sleep Medicine found a 37 percent increase in the rates of clinical insomnia among adults in China from before the peak of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $625,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Trump’s Campaign Talk of Troop Withdrawals Doesn’t Match Military Reality
description: President Trump has brought home few American combat troops over all even as his pressure campaign against Iran risks a new Middle East conflict.
content: When President Trump said on Twitter last week that all American troops in Afghanistan might be home by Christmas, he was reiterating a goal that has eluded him for years — and most likely hoping that when it comes to ending military deployments, voters will give him more credit for his messaging than for his results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Socially Distant, Except for the Dogs, Sheep and Chickens
description: On the farm with Isabella Rossellini, as she readies a streaming theater piece with cameos from her animal friends.
content: BELLPORT, N.Y. — From the sheep’s point of view, rehearsal had been going on long enough. On the lawn in front of Isabella Rossellini’s house, an elegant barn-to-home conversion in a chicly rural corner of Long Island, a few of them stood around baaing, waiting for their person to emerge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch and Christina Morales
title: Private Security Guard Held in Fatal Denver Shooting, Officials Say
description: The guard, Matthew Dolloff, had been hired as private security by a local news station that was covering dueling demonstrations on Saturday.
content: DENVER — A private security guard hired by a Denver television news station was being held by the authorities in connection with a fatal shooting that happened on Saturday after opposing rallies between far-right and far-left activists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember, Thomas Kaplan and Katie Glueck
title: Four Tricky Issues for the Biden-Harris Ticket
description: The campaign has learned it’s not always easy appealing to progressives in the party and moderates in the broader electorate.
content: During the vice-presidential debate last week, several issues came up, including the Supreme Court, climate change and taxes, that underscored the tightrope Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Kamala Harris are trying to walk as they seek to balance appeals to progressives and moderates alike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: Latino, Evangelical and Politically Homeless
description: Hispanic evangelicals identify as religious first and foremost. That’s why, despite his harsh rhetoric on immigration, many back President Trump.
content: PHOENIX — At the Church of God of Prophecy, hundreds come each Sunday for two hours of worship in Spanish. They share passages from the Bible, sing and embrace each other tightly. The evangelical congregation, led for nearly 25 years by Pastor Jose Rivera, is nearly all Latino, the vast majority with roots in Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
title: Trump’s Virus Treatment Revives Questions About Unchecked Nuclear Authority
description: Even before the president was given mood-altering drugs, there was a movement to end the commander in chief’s sole authority to launch nuclear weapons.
content: President Trump’s long rants and seemingly erratic behavior last week — which some doctors believe might have been fueled by his use of dexamethasone, a steroid, to treat Covid-19 — renewed a long-simmering debate among national security experts about whether it is time to retire one of the early inventions of the Cold War: the unchecked authority of the president to launch nuclear weapons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: Virus Hits Foreign Farmhands, Challenging Canadians’ Self-Image
description: Outbreaks at farms have made Canadians question how well their system is really protecting vulnerable migrant workers.
content: SIMCOE, Ontario — Three weeks after they began cutting asparagus in the thawing fields, Luis Gabriel Flores Flores noticed that one of his co-workers was missing. He said he found the man shivering with a fever, in bed — where he would remain for a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: At the French Open, Players Look to the Tao of Rafael Nadal
description: For many of the players, Nadal has given the most cleareyed view of a tournament held during a pandemic and a career chasing Grand Slam titles.
content: PARIS — Playing to his Paris audience, Rafael Nadal usually speaks in French for his on-court interviews at Roland Garros, where his astounding success on the red clay has afforded him abundant practice at polishing his sentences. But on Sunday, after winning his 13th French Open singles championship, Nadal, usually so unrelenting in his routine, dispensed with this particular habit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Sei Young Kim Wins Women’s P.G.A. Championship, Her First Major Title
description: Kim, 27, who entered the event as a 10-time winner on the tour, shot a seven-under 63 on Sunday to win her first major.
content: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa. — Sei Young Kim shot a sensational seven-under 63 on Sunday to earn her first major title at the Women’s P.G.A. Championship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: The Concerts Were Canceled Months Ago. So Where Are the Refunds?
description: As fans await money for called-off shows at the Nassau Coliseum, officials say they are the responsibility of the company run by a Russian oligarch who had operated the venue.
content: Early this year, Joanne Brakatselos, a rock fan in Queens, spent just over $1,000 for tickets to six concerts. In the months since those events were canceled because of the coronavirus, she got her money back for every show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Training Tomorrow’s Newshounds
description: Two new books about the press urge young people to leave their social media feeds and read reliable news and information from many different sources.
content: GUARDIANS OF LIBERTYFreedom of the Press and the Nature of NewsBy Linda Barrett Osborne
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaina Plott
title: In a small Alabama town, a mayoral candidate found herself at the center of rumors that she wanted to ‘defund the police.’
description: Perhaps no one was more surprised to learn that Joyce Jones wanted to defund the police than Joyce Jones herself.
content: Perhaps no one was more surprised to learn that Joyce Jones wanted to defund the police than Joyce Jones herself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaina Plott
title: In a Small Alabama Town, Suddenly All Politics Is National
description: The race for mayor in Montevallo used to be low-key and nonpartisan. In the Trump era, one candidate learned the hard way that’s no longer the case.
content: MONTEVALLO, Ala. — Perhaps no one was more surprised to learn that Joyce Jones wanted to defund the police than Joyce Jones herself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Are Amazon Jobs Worth 1,400 Loads of Traffic? French Region Is Split
description: The picturesque Gard desperately needs more employment. But environmentalists are pushing back at what they see as a looming blight.
content: FOURNÈS, France — On a sultry September morning, Claudie Cortellini headed into the vineyards to survey the grapes that go into her family’s heady Côtes du Rhône wines. In recent years, she has fought to ensure a good harvest as the climate grows warmer. But these days, she is facing an even bigger foe: a giant Amazon sorting center slated for construction near her land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meir Soloveichik
title: Leave Judge Barrett’s Faith Out of This
description: Examine her jurisprudence, not her religious practice.
content: One of the most enduring descriptions of American pluralism was composed by a religious Jew. In 1790, Moses Seixas led the dwindling Jewish community of the Touro Synagogue in Newport, R.I. He had struggled to sustain the religious observances that endowed Jews with a distinct identity: public readings of the Torah, circumcisions of baby boys, and the keeping of kosher dietary laws. Soon Newport’s remaining Jews would depart for other communities as opportunity there dwindled, and Seixas could have easily been forgotten in the annals of American history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Growald, Peter Gill Case and Valerie Rockefeller
title: Three Rockefellers Say Banks Must Stop Financing Fossil Fuels
description: JPMorgan Chase and other big banks should use their lending power to force cuts in greenhouse gas emissions.
content: One hundred years ago, as a deadly influenza gripped the world and the stock market dropped precipitously, our great-grandfather John D. Rockefeller Jr. began investing in New York banks to diversify the family’s business away from fossil fuels in the midst of the economic uncertainty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Markian Hawryluk
title: Need to Find a Pandemic Necessity? There’s Now a Store for That
description: Covid-19 Essentials may be the country’s first retail chain dedicated solely to products required because of an infectious disease.
content: LONE TREE, Colo. — Darcy Velasquez and her mother, Roberta Truax, were walking recently in the Park Meadows mall about 15 miles south of downtown Denver, looking for Christmas gifts for Ms. Velasquez’s two children, when they spotted a store with a display of rhinestone-studded masks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson, Benjamin Hoffman, Ben Shpigel and Bill Pennington
title: N.F.L. Week 5 Results: Cowboys Field Goal Salvages Win Over Giants
description: Dallas beat the winless Giants but lost starting quarterback Dak Prescott, who was carted off the field with what appeared to be a severe injury to his right leg.
content: Around the league, as Bill Pennington writes, “Through four weeks of the 2020 season, the average combined score of a game is 51.3 points, an increase of 16 percent over the same period a year ago and a roughly 20 percent increase in the average score of games since 2000.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: This week’s presidential debate has officially been canceled.
description: The second presidential debate, originally scheduled for Oct. 15 in Miami, has been canceled by the Commission on Presidential Debates, according to a statement released on Friday by the group.
content: The second presidential debate, originally scheduled for Oct. 15 in Miami, has been canceled by the Commission on Presidential Debates, according to a statement released on Friday by the group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Feared Shabab Exploit Somali Banking and Invest in Real Estate, U.N. Says
description: Despite sanctions, Shabab militants have found ways to extort, move and invest money using Somalia’s banking system, a United Nations panel says.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Shabab, the Somalia-based militant group that is Al Qaeda’s most powerful ally in Africa, is not only collecting millions of dollars in tariffs and payoffs but moving the money through local banks and even investing it in real estate and businesses, according to a new United Nations Security Council report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Follow J. Kenji López-Alt’s lead, and set up some “culinary building blocks” — shortcuts to fast flavor — to improve your weeknight cooking.
content: Good morning. J. Kenji López-Alt wrote a fascinating article for The Times last week about improving your cooking by using “culinary building blocks” — homemade and store-bought sauces and compotes and condiments — to build fast flavor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Pakistan Bans TikTok, Citing Morals. Others Cite Politics.
description: Conservatives have raised questions about public decency on the Chinese-owned service, but opposition groups see an efforts to stop criticism of the country’s leadership.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan has become the latest country to ban TikTok, the Chinese-owned social media platform, in a move that government critics said stemmed as much from politics as from allegations of immoral content.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor, Shane Goldmacher and Trip Gabriel
title: Jaime Harrison Raises $57 Million as Democratic Cash Floods Senate Races
description: The amount is the highest quarterly fund-raising total for any Senate candidate in U.S. history and part of an extraordinary surge of money pouring into Democrats’ campaigns.
content: Jaime Harrison, the Democrat challenging Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, raised an astonishing $57 million from July through September, the highest quarterly fund-raising total for any Senate candidate in U.S. history and part of a flood of Democratic money remaking the battle for control of the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Libby Peterson
title: When Animals Are as Photogenic as the Star
description: The idea: a portrait session with the actress Isabella Rossellini that involves sheep, dogs and chickens. She was totally game. Thankfully, so were the creatures.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: A Classic Western Sheriff on the Other Side of the World
description: In “Mystery Road,” Aaron Pedersen plays a lawman with Indigenous roots and John Wayne style.
content: While America debates how it wants its television cops to look and act — or whether it wants them at all — the rest of the world is happily sending us theirs. This month alone we’ve received cop or cop-adjacent shows from Armenia (“Special Division,” MHz Choice), Brazil (“Good Morning, Verônica,” Netflix), Britain (“Code 404,” Peacock), Canada (“Coroner,” CW) and France (“The Crimson Rivers” and “The Paris Murders,” PBS Masterpiece Prime Video).
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘My First Piña Colada Was the Summer Before Seventh Grade’
description: A drink brings back childhood memories, a game goes on and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bonnie Tsui
title: Support Independent Restaurants
description: As the weather gets colder in many places, mom-and-pop establishments are under even more strain. You can take some simple steps to help them survive.
content: Even with outdoor dining this summer, many restaurants across the country have closed or remain on the brink of disaster — especially smaller, independently owned neighborhood businesses. Loyal patrons have rallied to support their favorite local restaurants, but as the pandemic drags on, business owners have had to hustle hard to stay afloat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Tompkins
title: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer says she is concerned about the rise of right-wing armed groups in Michigan.
description: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan, who was targeted last week in a planned kidnapping operation by an armed group, whose alleged members have been arrested, said on Sunday that she remains worried about the presence of right-wing militias in her state.
content: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan, who was targeted last week in a planned kidnapping operation by an armed group, whose alleged members have been arrested, said on Sunday that she remains worried about the presence of right-wing militias in her state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: ‘Call Me a Dreamer’: A Shattered Beirut Neighborhood Rebuilds
description: Many worry that a full recovery won’t be possible, but residents of one of Beirut’s most diverse and cosmopolitan areas are moving back in and trying to repair the damage from the August explosion.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — After the August port explosion that disfigured much of Beirut, many compared the city to a phoenix that would rise again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Nancy Pelosi merely panned the White House’s $1.8 trillion relief offer, but Republicans revolted against it.
description: Senate Republicans revolted over the contours of a $1.8 trillion relief proposal that is the Trump administration’s latest and largest offer to House Democrats, further jeopardizing already dim prospects for an agreement on a broad stimulus bill before Election Day.
content: Senate Republicans revolted over the contours of a $1.8 trillion relief proposal that is the Trump administration’s latest and largest offer to House Democrats, further jeopardizing already dim prospects for an agreement on a broad stimulus bill before Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor, Russ Buettner and Neil Vigdor
title: Eric Trump conceded that his father ‘lost a fortune,’ but dismissed questions about influence-peddling.
description: President Trump’s son Eric on Sunday angrily dismissed a New York Times investigation showing that more than 200 companies, special-interest groups and foreign governments obtained favors from the Trump administration while patronizing Mr. Trump’s properties, earning the president millions of dollars.
content: President Trump’s son Eric on Sunday angrily dismissed a New York Times investigation showing that more than 200 companies, special-interest groups and foreign governments obtained favors from the Trump administration while patronizing Mr. Trump’s properties, earning the president millions of dollars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Supreme Court Hearing Presents a Big Stage, and Big Risks, for Harris
description: Though a junior member of the panel, the vice-presidential contender will draw heightened scrutiny as the Senate Judiciary Committee takes up Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s nomination.
content: WASHINGTON — Just seconds into the Supreme Court confirmation hearing of Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh in 2018, Senator Charles E. Grassley, then the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, was interrupted by a sharp demand to be recognized from far down the Democratic side of the dais.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: A new poll shows little change in the race since Trump’s coronavirus diagnosis.
description: A Washington Post/ABC News poll released Sunday shows Joseph R. Biden Jr. leading President Trump by 12 percentage points, similar both to his margin in a Post/ABC poll last month and to his margins in polls released by several other organizations in the past week.
content: A Washington Post/ABC News poll released Sunday shows Joseph R. Biden Jr. leading President Trump by 12 percentage points, similar both to his margin in a Post/ABC poll last month and to his margins in polls released by several other organizations in the past week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Wu
title: New York’s Commercial Rents Are ‘Too Damn High’
description: They’re making it harder for the city to recover. Here’s how to lower them.
content: What’s getting in the way of a recovery for New York City’s small businesses? Continued weak demand is surely the main factor. But the fact that commercial rents remain artificially inflated compounds the problem. More businesses could survive, more commercial spaces repurposed for other uses and more new businesses started if commercial rents actually reflected market conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Premier League Reform Plan Seeks to Reshape English Soccer
description: A proposal engineered by Liverpool and Manchester United would yield an 18-team Premier League and hundreds of millions of dollars in payments to lower leagues. But key players are not on board.
content: Taken together, the proposals amount to the biggest changes in English soccer in more than a quarter of a century. An 18-team Premier League. Hundreds of millions of dollars in extra payments from Premier League clubs to their poorer rivals. And an end of direct payment to clubs relegated from the top division.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Sweetie
description: Let’s tiptoe through the clues of this Joe Hansen puzzle.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Joe Hansen is a 2020 addition to the constructor pack; his only other Times puzzle until now was back in April and similarly offbeat. This is an intricate-looking grid that presents a good challenge, mainly because the key to “getting” it isn’t laid out for you in the clues. Even though there is a two-part revealer that provides a hint, you have to do some visual and literal deduction to find your hidden set of theme entries. Some toughies in the fill, and some interesting and creative entries, contribute to the gratification of figuring everything out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Parties Offer Divergent Portraits of Barrett as Senate Opens Hearings
description: Democrats will portray President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee as an ideologue, while Republicans will paint her as an accomplished working mother.
content: The Senate on Monday will dive into an extraordinary week of Supreme Court confirmation hearings for Judge Amy Coney Barrett, with Republicans and Democrats offering two starkly divergent portraits of a nominee who would tilt the court decisively to the right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kassie Bracken, Alexandra Eaton, Ben Laffin, Yousur Al-Hlou and Aaron Byrd
title: What’s the Problem With Vote-by-Mail? Hint: It’s Not Fraud
description: Vote-by-mail has become one of the most contentious issues of the 2020 election. But while battles rage on social media and in the courts, a group of bipartisan Michigan election officials worry they won’t have the time or resources to ensure results on election night.
content: Vote-by-mail has become one of the most contentious issues of the 2020 election. But while battles rage on social media and in the courts, a group of bipartisan Michigan election officials worry they won’t have the time or resources to ensure results on election night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Lett
title: 4 Podcasts That Go Bump in the Night
description: These shows are perfect for Halloween creeps and scares. Listen, if you dare.
content: When it comes to horror, no C.G.I. monstrosity is quite as terrifying as what your mind can conjure. We’ve collected some of the most delightful frights and spooky scintillations in audio drama and non-fiction podcasting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: An Arrest in Canada Casts a Shadow on a New York Times Star, and The Times
description: A top editor is now reviewing Rukmini Callimachi’s reporting on terrorism, which turned distant conflicts into accessible stories but drew criticism from colleagues.
content: Derek Henry Flood wasn’t looking for work in March of 2018, when he sent a direct message to a New York Times reporter he admired, Rukmini Callimachi, to congratulate her on the announcement of her big new podcast about the terror group known as the Islamic State.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Change the Supreme Court? You Have Ideas
description: We asked readers if and how you would alter the way justices are chosen and how the court works, and received more than 1,500 responses. Some of your suggestions would require constitutional amendments.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
